Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Diffuse interstellar clouds as the key step in galaxy evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
Cold atomic clouds are a necessary step on the way to molecular cloud and star formation. To study how these clouds form out of the warm neutral medium, Dr. Stanimirovic will use two next-generation radio facilities for sensitive HI absorption observations of the Milky Way and the Magellanic Clouds. The so-named "21-SPONGE" survey will provide the first quantitative description of the basic physical properties of the warm neutral medium in the Milky Way. A second survey conducted at facilities in the southern hemisphere will provide the census of cold gas in the Magellanic Clouds. These surveys will be complemented by a study of interstellar turbulence as a potential key agent for seeding the cold cloud formation. Once the data is obtained, a systematic comparison of synthetic HI spectra derived from numerical models with observations will test the reliability of simulated data sets and will expose missing physical processes.

The exploration of the interstellar clouds in the Milky Way continues to introductory astronomy classes at the University of Wisconsin, Madison through the development of the Astronomical Observation Laboratory -- a "radio observatory" dedicated to student learning. Three undergraduate students will work with Dr. Stanimirovic to develop radio astronomy tutorials suitable for lower-level astronomy classes. With its three small radio telescopes, the Astronomical Observation Laboratory will also allow upper-level, project-based courses to focus on problem-solving and collaborative learning. Undergraduate students from other campuses will be able to use Astronomical Observation Laboratory remotely from their classrooms and work with the radio tutorials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The formation of cold neutral medium is the first step in the star-formation cycle in galaxies; before the formation of stellar and planetary systems, diffuse interstellar gas needs to transform into cold, dense clouds. To provide the first quantitative description of the basic properties of the diffuse neutral gas in the Milky Way, this project undertook a large (~600 hours) survey with the Jansky Very Large Array in New Mexico. In the direction of 58 background radio sources, we obtained very sensitive neutral hydrogen absorption spectra. The survey  allowed us to constrain temperature distribution and fractions of neutral gas over the range from 10 K to ~10,000 K. The high temperature end of this distribution has remained observationally unconstrained for many years due to its low optical depth. By combining all our hydrogen spectra we have demonstrated that the warm neutral gas exists in the interstellar medium at a high excitation temperature of ~7000 K. This is a surprising result that will require future theoretical and observational studies to fully understand the  origin and excitation mechanisms of the high-temperature component. Our survey has served as an excellent comparison set for complex numerical simulations. We have used about 10,000 synthetic spectra produced by numerical simulations to investigate biases of our analysis methods, as well as to identify physical processes that are still not fully represented in numerical simulations (e.g. the excitation of hydrogen atoms, and the Milky Way rotation pattern). To assist the analysis of hydrogen spectra, the project has developed and implemented a novel algorithm for decomposing spectra into Gaussian functions. This machine-learning based algorithm has generated significant interest in the community, it has been highly beneficial for this project, and is now being widely used in many other astronomy projects.

This award has also focused on understanding the properties and origin of interstellar turbulence in the Milky Way and the nearby Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC). A novel method was developed, based on numerical simulations of the hydrogen column density, to spatially map out the level of turbulence across the SMC. Also, a statistical approach has been used to search for the increased level of turbulence in the vicinity of star-forming regions in the SMC.  Several followup studies are currently underway.

Broader Impacts:

One postdoctoral scholar, 2 graduate students (one PhD thesis), and six undergraduate students have contributed to this project. More than ten refereed-journal publications have been supported by this award. In addition, several projects have been developed using Small Radio Telescopes (SRT) for undergraduate students in both lower and upper-level astronomy courses at the University of Wisconsin. Students have experienced hands-on how the scientific process works by obtaining and analyzing SRT observations, and connecting their results with astronomy concepts covered in undergraduate classes.
